case_vignette: A 12-year-old female presents with    hemorrhagic crusts on the lips and erosions of the oral, genital, and conjunctival mucosa for 2 days. According to the paren   ts, there    was a pneumonia outbreak at school.  The patient also h   ad a high fever and cough a week before  the onset of cutaneous lesions. The parents deny any new medication and a history of alle   rgies. The physical exam reveals no other skin  findings.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have bleeding crusts on my lips and sores in my mouth, genital area, and eyes that started 2 days ago.
Have you had any recent medication changes or started any new medications?
No, I haven't started any new medications or made any changes recently.
Do you have any known allergies to medications, foods, or environmental factors?
No, I don't have any history of allergies.
Have you experienced any recent fevers, joint pains, or changes in your vision along with the other symptoms?
I had a high fever and a cough a week ago, but no joint pains or changes in my vision.
Do you have any history of autoimmune diseases, either personally or in your family?
No, I don't have any personal or family history of autoimmune diseases.
Final Diagnosis: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
